narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Phenomenal Class. I learned how to approach reading and dissecting papers, how basic science can be used in the clinical setting, and how to write an entire grant proposal.

I learned about a variety of different diseases and the molecular mechanisms underlying those diseases. It was great to apply principles of biochemistry to real life diseases and see how the mechanisms we have learned in class actually impact people. Since most of the work was reading papers and being prepared to discuss and answer questions about them, this course also helped me with my scientific paper reading skills.
A stronger ability to read, understand, and criticize scientific literature
how to critically evaluate research and papers, and design our own studies

I gained the ability to critically read scientific papers and further understand the basic science to clinical applications approach. This class was so essential for learning how to more effectively read scientific papers and I would highly recommend it to anyone in the MB&B major!

Seeing the direct link between basic science research and advancements in treatment or diagnosis in medicine. Critically analyzing primary literature with the goal of understanding both the experimental techniques as well as larger goals of each paper.
This course was relevant and informative. I gained a great knowledge regarding the molecular basis of many diseases and further deepened my knowledge of how lab science reaches clinical applications.

I learned how to interpret data, how to design experiments, and how basic science discoveries can be translated to clinical science. I also learned about various diseases, cellular pathways, and experimental protocols, with a focus on DNA and RNA. This class also gave me the opportunity to collaborate with my classmates and to think through scientific problems together.

I developed a greater understanding of reading and interpreting basic science literature in the context of a wide range of diseases, underlying mechanisms and significance of those diseases, and improved my scientific writing skills in the form of a mini-review and a research proposal.
Reading scientific papers.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course is well-designed, and each of the guest lecturers contributes something unique and interesting with their lectures, though it might be helpful to suggest that students read the assigned review papers anytime between when they're posted and the discussion day (instead of reading all the papers between the lecture and discussion) so that they don't have to read 6-7 papers within the span of 2 days.

strength - learned a lot from a variety of professors, group STEM work was a new experience that I enjoyed
weaknesses - would like to do more proposing our own experiments, as that is where I feel I fell the most short on graded assignments
This course was extremely well organized and I so enjoyed the weekly discussion sections, and the preparedness of everyone in the class.

A wide range of diseases are discussed with several viruses and various genetic disorders. I think it would be nice if there were a lecture (preferably earlier in the semester) specifically dealing with cancer. A number of diseases pertinent to telomere biology or genomic (in)stability alluded to consequences in cancer, but without background knowledge on cancer and its mechanisms, this could have been missed by some students.
The strengths of this course are the professors who presented at each weekly lecture and the topics/papers selected for analysis and discussion.

Strengths: getting to learn about a variety of diseases and to understand translational medicine, hearing from a variety of faculty who are each experts in their field, learning from my classmates and getting to hear their insights in the discussion sections; the TAs were very helpful in guiding our discussions and in providing feedback on our writing assignments

Weaknesses: more guidance would have been helpful for both the mini-review and the final paper; sometimes the turnover time between the Monday lecture and the Wednesday discussion section was not enough to get through all the assigned readings, spacing out the work/reading would have been nice (because we had basically no work to do from Wednesday-Monday); the diseases we studied were heavily focused on the DNA and RNA levels, and I personally would have appreciated learning about some diseases more from a protein/signal transduction perspective.
It would be nice to have more guidance writing the mini review and final proposal, as not all students have experience with this kind of writing, especially with the final proposal.

I think that this course was difficult, by nature, to have on Zoom but that the professors and TAs did a great job adapting the course in an online setting. Strengths: inspiring professors and lectures, interesting source material, interactive weekly discussions
I wish we had had more time to develop our proposal, and a scheduled one-on-one discussion time over Zoom (given the virtual constraints) discussing our proposal topic would have been very helpful!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: virtual engagement in breakout room discussion sections
I believe the synchronous components of the lecture and discussion sections succeeded.

It was pretty successful in this regard. Every other meeting was a seminar, and the lectures allowed numerous questions and discussion, so it felt very engaging. The TAs were very responsive over email for help with the writing assignments too.
The real-time virtual lectures and discussion sections worked well.

The Wednesday discussion sections worked surprisingly well over Zoom. We were able to all work on a Google Doc on our computers and talk to each other in our Zoom breakout rooms. Obviously being in person would have facilitated discussions better and would have afforded us the opportunity to get to know each other better, but overall, we were still able to collaborate well over Zoom.
Most Monday lectures went very smoothly over Zoom.

The break out rooms for discussion sections were a good attempt at fostering discussion, but often led to the same people being grouped together every week. 
Overall, having the entire class live (including the lectures) was very very important for this course and being able to meet so many different professors and learn about their research was really exciting!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. This is probably the best class in the MBB major, so please take it!
Yes, especially if you're looking for a class that can contextualize biochemical principles with human disease.
Yes, especially if you intend to go into grad school or medical schoola strong background in reading and understanding scientific literature is invaluable
it's an MBB requirement that is enjoyable!
I would recommend this course absolutely to any student in the  major! It will dramatically improve one's ability to critically evaluate scientific papers.
I would recommend it. After going through MB&B 300/301, its a lot easier and, in my opinion, more rewarding. Its a solid MB&B elective that is certainly memorable.
I would recommend this course to another student highly interested in connecting lab science to real-world, clinical applications.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. I got to learn about a variety of diseases, and I gained a deeper appreciation for the advances of basic science in the realm of medicine. This class also helped me understand how material from earlier biology classes, particularly MB&B 301, was relevant in medicine, and seeing those concepts in action was a particularly rewarding experience. This would be a great class for any student interested in pursuing an MD-PhD.
I would recommend this course to anyone who has a research background. I don't think it's possible to follow along with the class without at least a summer's worth of research experience in biology.
Yes, if the student is interested in a career in research, medicine, or a combination of both!
Yes!
